Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Studies of Property Rights and Merger Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds work on two distinct projects. The Cose Theorem instructs that the allocation of property rights is irrelevant for economic outcomes; as long as all parties affected by a decision can engage in efficient bargaining, the allocation of property rights will not matter. While a sueful benchmark, economists have long recognized that in many circumstances such bargaining is not possible. The first project focuses on one reason: inefficient bargaining due to asymmetric information. Put simply, when bargaining is imperfect because the parties do not have the same information, the status quo position of the parties may matter for the final agreements reached. This research works to analyse how property rights should be be distribued to maximize economic welfare under these circumstances. The project expands on previous results by investigating issues such as the nature of second best property rights when efficiency cannot be achieved, the benefits of options-to-own over simple property rights, the effects of alternative bargaining procedures, and optimal property rights in dynamic settings. This would may improve our understanding of issues as diverse as the optimal assignment of of intellectual property rights, the benefits of liability rules versus property rules in law, the efficienciy of alternative mthods of allocating spectrum, and the organization of productive partnerships. The intellectual merit of the project is that it seeks to expand our understanding of how the proper allocation of property rights can increase effciency by facilitating trade. The broader impacts are that the allocation of property rights plays an important role in numerous practical economic progblems.

The second project examines the nature of an optimal horizontal merger policy, one fo the central pillars of antitrust policy. The project characterizes an optimal dynamic merger policy in a setting with stochastically arriving merger possibilities and ex ante uncertain levels of synergies in which the firms decide each period which mergers to propose to the antitrust authoirty. It identifies conditions in which this difficult issue has a strikingly simple resolution: an antitrust authority who wants to maximize consumer welfare can accomplish the objective by using a completely myopic merger review policy; that is, one that approves a merger today if and only if it deos not lower consumer surplus given the current market structure. New work on this project includes the relaxation of an important assumption, that the set of firms involved in one possible merger does not overlap with those in any other possible mergers. The broader impacts of this project include developing better-informed antitrust policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Work on this project resulted in 6 publications and one working paper currently under submission

  1. “Dynamic Merger Review,” Journal of Political Economy (118), December 2010, 1200-51. (with V. Nocke)
  2. “A Simple Status Quo that Ensures Participation (with Application to Efficient Bargaining),” Theoretical Economics (6), January 2011, 109-25. (with I. Segal)
  3. “Property Rights,” Chapter 3 in R. Gibbons and J. Roberts, eds., Handbook of Organizational Economics, Princeton University Press, 2013. (with I. Segal)
  4. “Merger Policy with Merger Choice,” American Economic Review (103), April 2013, 1006-33. (with V. Nocke)
  5. “The Efficiency of Bargaining Under Divided Entitlements,” University of Chicago Law Review (81), Winter 2014, 273-89. (with I. Segal)
  6. “Property Rights and the Efficiency of Bargaining,” Journal of the European Economic Association, December 2016, 1287-1328. (with I. Segal)
  7. "Internal versus External Growth in Industries with Scale Economies: A Dynamoc Model of Optimal Merger Policy" (with B. Mermelstein, V. Nocke, and M. Satterthwaite)

Publications (2), (5), and (6) all study the effects of property rights in settings in which parties bargain with private information about the values each derives from an agreement. In (2) we identify a fairly general class of environments in which a particular property rights allocation, that we call the "expected efficient allocation," can induce a first-best (efficient) result from such a bargaining process.  In (6) we derive the optimal property rights in a class of environments (different from those in (2)) in which the first best is not achievable.  (5) shows how these results can inform the legal literature's comparison of legal entitlements (property rights vs. liability rules), first made famous by Calabresi and Melamed. (3) is a more general survey of the property rights literature, in which we also present some new results.

Publications (1) and (4), and working paper (7) analyze optimal horizontal merger policy in dynamic environments.  (1) derives a benchmark result, identifying circumstances in which a static (myopic) merger policy, that approves a merger if it raises welfare at the time at which it is proposed, is fully dynamically optimal. (4) and (7) consider environements that do not conform with the conditions identified in (1), and identifies optimal merger policy.  In (4), an acquirer is choosing between several merger partners, and has private information about the mergers that are actually feasible that the antitrust authority does not possess. We show conditions under which the antitrust authority should optimally bias its decisions against larger mergers in order to induce a more desirable choice of merger partner. In (7) we consider a much richer environment in which firms may invest in building capital, and benefit from scale economies.  A merger that combines firms' capital stocks may therefore result in marginal cost reductions, but so could continued investment by independent firms. We analyze the model computationally, showing the difference between optimal static and dynamic policies, as well as the effect of the antitrust being able to commit to its policy.
